results.title: Wallace & Gromit: a grand day out
results.brief_description: Wallace likes a nice bit of cheese with his crackers, so when the eccentric inventor finds his fridge empty and the local corner shop shut for Bank Holiday, he is forced to look further afield for his cheddar. His faithful dog Gromit is used to his master’s flights of fancy, but this time his ears prick up with excitement as the two plasticene heroes blast off in their home-made rocket on the ultimate day-trip to the Moon! For children and adults alike, the animation techniques used in this production are quite incredible.

results.title: Wall of fear
results.brief_description: A widow, her son and mother newly settled in new location is terrified by a hoodlum, whom she had earlier humiliated in front of a crows od younger kids, when she slapped his face after she caught him ill-treating a younger boy. Her efforts to enlist the aid of the police, and others, are fruitless, she takes into her own hands, obtains a revolver, catches the terrorist in her son’s bedroom. The subsequent scenes show how she obtained a new friend. Cast includes; Susan Douglas, Eleanor Beecroft, Douglas Master, Jena Keller and herb Fisher.

results.title: Walking with my sisters (A)
results.creator_credit: Big Cat Productions and Bronwyn Kidd
results.brief_description: Walking with my sisters is an engaging documentary about the struggle of three Aboriginal sisters to have their native title rights acknowledged and their land returned to them. The three Aboriginal sisters - Lorna Kelly, Linda Vidler and Yvonne Graham - are the traditional custodians of the Byron Bay area, and a main criterion they must meet in the claims process is to prove that they are in fact descendents of this land and not migrants from elsewhere. “Walking with my sisters” gives a broad outline of the various steps involved in making native title claims, such as the endless negotiations and the many interested parties and competing interests. Behind this complex process, however, lies the fact that Indigenous peoples were the original inhabitants of the land and that part of the ongoing process of reconciliation and defining Australia’s past and future involves grappling with this truth. Filmed over several years, “Walking with my sisters” shows a positive outcome to a long and deeply felt battle against what - at large - can be identified as cultural denial.

results.title: Walking with dinosaurs: The Ballad of Big Al
results.brief_description: Narrated by Kenneth Brannagh and using the computer graphic and animatronic techniques created by the team behind the amazing “Walking with Dinosaurs” series, this program resurrects Big Al, an Allosaurus who lived 145 million years ago. The first program is the recreated story of his 15-year life, a constant battle against formidable prey and voracious predators. The second program is a scientific detective story which traces the evidence of Big Al. Using the same graphic effects, we follow Big Al as he roams museums and archaeological dig sites where we see passionate scientists explaining the research behind his tale.

results.title: Walking with cavemen: with Robert Winston
results.creator_credit: BBC, Discovery Channel, ProSieben, Peter Georgi and Richard Dale
results.brief_description: From the same team that produced “The Human Body” comes another fascinating and well-made documentary series presented by Robert Winston. In a four part series all on the same DVD, the history of human evolution from ancient apes to the present modern man is traversed in chronological order. Starting with ‘The First Ancestors’ the first ape from Africa to stand on two legs is discovered. Using the latest ‘animatic’ technology the viewer is privy to the ancient world and these creatures using a mixture of computer generated images and actors in monkey suits - done in a style that makes for compelling viewing. Not only physical traits but also the lifestyle of Neanderthal man is shown. The series climaxes with the discovery of one key element that makes modern man different - the gift of imagination.

results.title: Walking with beasts [DVD]
results.brief_description: 65 million years ago the reign of the dinosaur ended. This BBC series is about what happened next. Nearly every creature over ten kilograms had been wiped out, leaving little creatures, like mammals to flourish. Mammals eventually took over the world over the next 20 million years, laying claim to earth and sea. This series presents the evolution of a multitude of mammals - exotic creatures such as the leptictidium, ambulocetus, dinofelis, gastronis, basilosaurus and the moeritherium, to name a few. Mastery of computer-generated images and animation, coupled with an atmospheric soundtrack, makes for colourful and realistic re-creations of the ways in which these magnificent animals operated in their fertile environments. Divided into six episodes - New dawn, Whale killer, Land of giants, Next of kin, Sabre tooth and Mammoth journey - each section focuses on a different type of mammal, covering such topics as species development, predators, laws of the animal kingdom, habits, habitats and changes to the earth’s ecosystems. At times this spectacular work, with its entertaining and gripping visuals, is capable of depicting graphically gory predatory behaviour. Also covers the age of the Neanderthal, and early stages of man versus beast. The breadth of background research is evident - awe-inspiring visuals are coupled with an informative and entertaining commentary. Narrated by Kenneth Branagh.

results.title: Walking together; Talkin' business; Making things right (A)
results.creator_credit: Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and Lew Griffiths
results.brief_description: These three programs and a kit aim to support the Council of Aboriginal Reconciliation’s vision for a united Australia “which respects this land of ours; values Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage and provides justice and equity for all.” ‘Walking together’ and ‘Talkin’ Business’ highlights the aims and operation of the Council and ‘Making things right’ discusses the implications of the Mabo decision.

results.title: Walking through a minefield (A)
results.creator_credit: Hatchling Productions, Australian Film Commission, SBS Independent, Cathy Henkel and Jeff Canin
results.brief_description: A thought provoking documentary on the contentious issue of uranium mining, and in particular the construction of the new Jabiluka uranium mine by mining company Energy Resources of Australia (ERA) in the Kakadu National Park. The film follows the daily conflicts which face the dedicated protesters who have arrived, on invitation by the Aboriginal traditional owners, from all over Australia to set up a blockade to prevent ERA beginning construction at Jabiluka. Through interviews and personal commentary, the filmmakers present the many and varied viewpoints held by all those involved from all sides of the fence including ERA workers and management, protesters, Aboriginal traditional owners, police officers, tourist operators, and residents of the nearby town of Jabiru. Uranium mining has social, economical and political consequences for Australia and the Australian population particularly in light of the government’s intention to allow other mining companies to further develop our uranium industry. A very interesting and insightful program. Narrated by Rachel Griffiths.
